_exec_summary.SummaryText:
2017 General Executive Summary for The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site and Dow Corning Corporation Midland Site, Midland, Michigan.





Revisions to the Plan



Revisions to the December 05, 2016 plan are being submitted on November 01, 2017 for the following reasons:



Classification of The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site and Dow Corning Corporation Midland Site as a Single Stationary Source:



The Dow Chemical Company (Dow) is now the owner of Dow Corning Corporation (Dow Corning). Dow Corning is therefore a wholly owned subsidiary of Dow. The two facilities are located on contiguous property separated by a public way. It is anticipated that Dow Corning will have a name change to remove the term Corning in February 2018. This RMP submittal includes both facilities as a single stationary source until and after such name change should occur. The combined stationary source will be referred to as the Michigan Operations Site.



Where procedures have not yet been integrated for the facilities, the reported program information will be date of the most recent review or revision for that program. i.e. heritage Dow and heritage Dow Corning will have different dates for some elements such as emergency response plan, hot work procedures, etc. Where procedures have been integrated the programs will have the same dates. 

The air operating permit for the Dow Corning portion of the stationary source is ROP-A4043-2008.  The DUNS for Dow Corning is 005353487. There is insufficient room in the registration section to list this information for both companies there. 

Rail Operations Decreased Maximum Inventory:

 

The Michigan Operations Site significantly decreased chlorine railcar maximum storage volume. 

 

Addition of Process Unit: 

The Michigan Operations Site is adding back the 827 DAS unit that ceased operation and was removed in 2016. This will include the addition of regulated substances above TQ associated with this process. 

 

Additio

n of Regulated Substances: 

The Michigan Operations Site added three regulated substances as they will be in use in the 827 DAS unit at the stationary source.



?    Ammonia

?    Crotonaldehyde

?    Sulfur Dioxide



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Michigan Operations Site is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility.  Appropriate controls are implemented to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If a release were to occur, highly trained emergency response personnel are on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  The facility also coordinates with the City of Midland Fire Department which can provide additional emergency response expertise.





Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The Michigan Operations Site's primary activity is chemical manufacturing, including agricultural and specialty chemicals, silicones and plastics.  There are forty-one (41) covered processes, fifty-six (56) programs and fifty-two (52) regulated substances present at the stationary source.  



The regulated substances are listed below.  Twelve of the chemicals in the list are not routinely stored on site and/or if present, are present in less than threshold amounts and have been added under the provision of predictive filing.  Predictive filing was done for flammable or toxic chemicals which may be included in mixtures received at the facility.



Worst and Alternative Case Scenario Selection

Where worst and alternate case scenarios impacted additional receptors, all scenarios were included in the submittal. There are five (5) worst case toxic and four (4) worst case flammable scenarios in this submittal. There are twenty (20) tota

l alternate cases, one of which is a flammable case. 



Regulated Substances:



1,3-Butadiene

1-Butene

1-Chloropropylene (predictive)

2-Butene

2-Chloropropylene (predictive)

2-Methyl-1-butene (predictive)

Methyltrichlorosilane

Vinyl acetate monomer

Vinyl ethyl ether (predictive)

Vinylidene chloride





The General Accidental Release Prevention Program



The Michigan Operations Site has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with applicable company and governing agency requirements at the time of construction.  Modifications to existing structures are also done in compliance with applicable company standards and governing agency requirements.  Several processes at the facility are subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management standard under 19 CFR 1910.119.  The facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program

that is in place at the Michigan Operations Site.





Process Safety Information



The Michigan Operations Site maintains detailed records of safety information that, among other things, describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment design associated with all covered processes.  Numerous types of information are available to supplement safety information, including Safety Data Sheets for materials used on site, equipment and engineering design specifications and applicable reactive chemicals testing.



Process Hazard Analysis



The Michigan Operations Site conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  For initial screening and risk evaluation, calculations of The Dow Chemical Fire and Explosion and Chemical Exposure Indices are performed, and a Reactive Chemical and Process Hazard Analysis is conducted.  These methodologies are supplemented when needed with analyses that may include:  What if Analysis, Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA), Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA), Fault Tree Analysis and Safer Technology and Alternative Analysis (STAA).  A team of qualified personnel performs the studies along with experts in engineering and process operations.  Any findings related to the hazard analyses are addressed in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures



For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, the Michigan Operations Site maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.



Training



The Michigan Operations Site has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that em

ployees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.



Mechanical Integrity



The Michigan Operations Site carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel receive specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of Change



Written procedures are in place at the Michigan Operations Site to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and receive training on the modification.



Pre-startup Reviews



Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications of existing processes are conducted as a regular practice at the Michigan Operations Site.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment and operating & maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits



The Michigan Operations Site conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule and other applicable regulatory requirements are being followed and have been implemented properly.  Audits are conducted using an established schedule for the site.  Corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.



Incident Investigation



The Mich

igan Operations Site promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the root causes leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring.  The facility also investigates minor and near miss type of incidents as a preventive measure.



Employee Participation



The Michigan Operations Site operates on the premise that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues, to attend applicable reviews, and to recommend improvements.  Improvements are solicited and implemented as appropriate.  In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.



Contractors



On occasion, the Michigan Operations Site hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  The facility has a strict program for informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes, as well as the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.  Contractors are also required to inform the facility of any hazards they may introduce or encounter while at the site.



Five-year Accident History



The Michigan Operations Site had a small Oleum release in 2016 that was contained on-site but had several workers nearby.  For precautionary reasons only, several personnel were sent to the Dow Medical Center for evaluation.  One individual experienced eye irritation requiring a prescription medicine resulting in a recordable injury and accident reporting.

Emergency Response Plan



The Michigan Operations Site maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan documents all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, and post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  The plan is updated as necessary to reflect any pertinent changes within the processes at the facility that would require a modified emergency response.



The facility works with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which the facility emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.



Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced in order to ensure that it is functioning properly at all times.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the accidental release prevention program.  Development of Environmental Health and Safety Work Processes, a concentrated Behavior Based Safety effort, and company-wide Environmental Health & Safety goals are some of the major steps taken to improve safety at the Source.  The Michigan Operations Site also works with the Department of Homeland Security to ensure full compliance with the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard.
